metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: The match statement is used to perform different actions based on different conditions.
content.html: The match statement is used to perform different actions based on different conditions.

content.text: Instead of writing many if..else statements, you can use the match statement.
content.html: Instead of writing many if..else statements, you can use the match statement.

content.text: The match statement selects one of many code blocks to be executed.
content.html: The match statement selects one of many code blocks to be executed.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
match expression:
  case x:
    code block
  case y:
    code block
  case z:
    code block

content.code:
match expression:
case x:
code block
case y:
code block
case z:
code block

syntax_highlighting.text:
match expression:
  case x:
    code block
  case y:
    code block
  case z:
    code block

content.code_html:
match expression:
  case x:
    code block
  case y:
    code block
  case z:
    code block

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
match expression:
  case x:
    code block
  case y:
    code block
  case z:
    code block

content.text: The example below uses the weekday number to print the weekday name:
content.html: The example below uses the weekday number to print the weekday name:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
day = 4
match day:
  case 1:
    print("Monday")
  case 2:
    print("Tuesday")
  case 3:
    print("Wednesday")
  case 4:
    print("Thursday")
  case 5:
    print("Friday")
  case 6:
    print("Saturday")
  case 7:
    print("Sunday")

content.code:
day = 4
match day:
case 1:
print("Monday")
case 2:
print("Tuesday")
case 3:
print("Wednesday")
case 4:
print("Thursday")
case 5:
print("Friday")
case 6:
print("Saturday")
case 7:
print("Sunday")

syntax_highlighting.text:

match day:
  case 1:
    print("Monday")
  case 2:
    print("Tuesday")
  case 3:
    print("Wednesday")
  case 4:
    print("Thursday")
  case 5:
    print("Friday")
  case 6:
    print("Saturday")
  case 7:
    print("Sunday")

content.code_html:

match day:

  case 5:

  case 6:

  case 3:

  case 4:
    print("Thursday")
  case 5:

  case 6:

  case 7:

content.text: Use the underscore character _ as the last case value if you want a code block to execute when there are not other matches:
content.html: Use the underscore character _ as the last case value if you want a code block to execute when there are not other matches:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
day = 4
match day:
  case 6:
    print("Today is Saturday")
  case 7:
    print("Today is Sunday")
  case _:
    print("Looking forward to the Weekend")

content.code:
day = 4
match day:
case 6:
print("Today is Saturday")
case 7:
print("Today is Sunday")
case _:
print("Looking forward to the Weekend")

syntax_highlighting.text:
day = 4
match day:
  case 6:
    print("Today is Saturday")
  case 7:
    print("Today is Sunday")
  case _:
    print("Looking forward to the Weekend")

content.code_html:
day = 4
match day:
  case 6:
    print("Today is Saturday")
  case 7:
    print("Today is Sunday")
  case _:
    print("Looking forward to the Weekend")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
day = 4
match day:
  case 6:
    print("Today is Saturday")
  case 7:
    print("Today is Sunday")
  case _:
    print("Looking forward to the Weekend")

content.text: The value _ will always match, so it is important to place it as the last case to make it beahave as a default case .
content.html: The value _ will always match, so it is important to place it as the last case to make it beahave as a default case.

content.text: Use the pipe character | as an or operator in the case evaluation to check for more than one value match in one case :
content.html: Use the pipe character | as an or operator in the case evaluation to check for more than one value match in one case:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
day = 4
match day:
  case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5:
    print("Today is a weekday")
  case 6 | 7:
    print("I love 
  weekends!")

content.code:
day = 4
match day:
case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5:
print("Today is a weekday")
case 6 | 7:
print("I love
weekends!")

syntax_highlighting.text:
day = 4
match day:
  case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5:
    print("Today is a weekday")
  case 6 | 7:
    print("I love 
  weekends!")

content.code_html:
day = 4
match day:
  case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5:
    print("Today is a weekday")
  case 6 | 7:
    print("I love weekends!")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
day = 4
match day:
  case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5:
    print("Today is a weekday")
  case 6 | 7:
    print("I love 
  weekends!")

content.text: You can add if statements in the case evaluation as an extra condition-check:
content.html: You can add if statements in the case evaluation as an extra condition-check:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
month = 5
day = 4
match day:
  case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 if month == 4:
    print("A weekday in April")
  case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 if month == 5:
    print("A weekday in May")
  case _:
    print("No match")

content.code:
month = 5
day = 4
match day:
case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 if month == 4:
print("A weekday in April")
case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 if month == 5:
print("A weekday in May")
case _:
print("No match")

syntax_highlighting.text:
month = 5
day = 4
match day:

    print("A weekday in April")
  case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 if month == 5:
    print("A weekday in May")
  case _:
    print("No match")

content.code_html:
month = 5
day = 4
match day:
  case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 if month == 4:
    print("A weekday in April")
  case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 if month == 5:
    print("A weekday in May")
  case _:
    print("No match")

day = 4

    print("A weekday in April")
  case 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 if month == 5:
    print("A weekday in May")
  case _:
    print("No match")

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Which character can be used as a default case value in a match statement?
